Examining the latest in health care policy every weekday morning 

            By 
Erin Mershon

10/06/15 10:01 AM EDT
With help from Rachana Pradhan and Brianna Ehley 
BROWN SIGNS "RIGHT TO DIE" BILL … WHO'S NEXT? — California Gov. Jerry Brown’s decision on Monday to sign a “right to die” bill into law could carry outsized influence in the country because of the state’s sheer size, say supporters of the measure. Advocates hope California will spur other states to approve similar bills so terminally ill patients can choose to receive life-ending medication from a doctor. “This is the biggest victory for the death-with-dignity movement since Oregon passed the nation’s first law two decades ago,” said Compassion & Choices President Barbara Coombs Lee, which lobbied heavily for the California legislation. “Enactment of this law in California means we are providing this option to more than 1 in 10 Americans.” Pro's Rachana Pradhan has the full story.
Story Continued Below
— But while the death last year of 29-year-old Brittany Maynard helped renew momentum for the effort in California, physician-assisted suicide is still encountering strong resistance elsewhere. According to the Death with Dignity National Center, which advocates for such laws, 25 state legislatures and the District of Columbia considered “right to die” bills during the 2015 legislative session, but only California’s took hold this year. California is now the fifth state to authorize the practice, joining Oregon, Montana, Vermont and Washington.
HAPPY TUESDAY and welcome to PULSE, where we are giving a belated shout out to Nobel Prize winner Youyou Tu for her work on the malaria parasite — work that's enabled your PULSEr's baby brother, who's in the middle of NIH fellowship focused on malarial transmission in primates. Fingers crossed he'll be accepting the award someday! Your PULSEr, meanwhile, is contenting herself with the "Most Improved" trophy she took home after three years on the high school swim team. Tips and comments: emershon@politico.com and behley@politico.com. 
"All I do is win win win no matter what. Got PULSE on my mind and I can never get enough."
ON TPP, PHARMA WASN'T THE ONLY LOSER — Pharma and biotech companies lost a major battle over IP protection for biologics, which has some of their allies questioning the final deal. Senate Finance Committee Chairman Orrin Hatch is already saying he'll have a hard time supporting a deal without a dozen years of protection for the drugs — despite wins he got on currency provisions. The winner in all the kerfuffle? The Generic Pharmaceutical Association, which is pleased as punch that negotiators secured "trade provisions that facilitate both the development of innovative, life-saving medicines and the availability of affordable generic medicines." Another big loser was Big Tobacco, which was prevented from challenging other member countries' tobacco control measures. Plenty more on all the winners and losers (everyone from the U.S. Chamber to the New Zealand dairy industry), here.
TODAY: CASSIDY, CONWAY AND MORE TALK COORDINATED CARE — Sen. Bill Cassidy is kicking off CAPG's 2015 conference this morning with a speech about value-based care — and he's set to criticize the Obama administration for its reliance on ACOs, your PULSEr hears. He'll highlight recent reports that indicate they're not performing as hoped, taking special aim at the idea of retrospective assignment of patients. He wants a system more like Medicare Advantage, he'll explain today. 
 — Also set to speak today: CMS's Patrick Conway, MedPAC's Mark Miller and insurance industry expert John Gorman. There's also a morning panel with health aides Karen Fisher of the Senate Finance Committee and Robert Horne of the House E&C Committee, and HHS Office of Health Reform Director Meena Seshamani. Your PULSEr will be there all morning — shoot me a note if you're around. 
UPTON, HATCH, PITTS TO BURWELL: WHERE'S THAT CHIP REPORT? — SFC Chair Orrin Hatch, E&C Chairman Fred Upton and health subcommittee chief Joe Pitts are out with a new letter blasting HHS for failing to deliver an ACA-mandated report on children's health insurance, which was originally due at the start of April. The report will analyze how CHIP plans stack up against exchange plans, and the lawmakers point out that it's now all the more pressing, since states were allowed to start enrolling CHIP kids in exchange plans as of Sept. 30. The lawmakers are giving HHS two weeks to update them on the status of the report. More here: http://1.usa.gov/1Oh680m 
REPORT WATCH: SG TAKES ON SUBSTANCE ABUSE — Next year will see the publication of the first-ever Surgeon General's report on substance abuse, addiction and health, SG Vivek Murthy announced at the Unite to Face Addiction Rally Sunday. "We’re going to look at the best science on everything, from heroin and marijuana, to alcohol and prescription opioids," he said. "And we’re going to launch a national campaign to tackle the prescription drug crisis, because we know that someone dies from an opioid overdose every 24 minutes in this country."
— It's a move that Majority Leader Mitch McConnell is already behind, and Sen. Ed Markey is also calling it "historic." Advocates hope it will transform the perception and understanding of substance abuse the way the 1964 Surgeon General's report on smoking launched the public health war against tobacco.
** A message from the American College of Rheumatology: More than 63 million Americans are living with doctor-diagnosed arthritis, autoimmune diseases or inflammatory rheumatic diseases, and are at risk for chronic pain, disability and even death. Advocates for Arthritis are asking Congress to support policies to ensure access to quality care for America’s rheumatology patients. Learn more at rheumatology.org/Advocacy. **
JUMPING THE MEDICARE ADVANTAGE SHIP — Patients who used high-cost services were more likely to abandon their Medicare Advantage plans in favor of traditional Medicare, according to a new study in Health Affairs. Patients who used nursing home care or home health care were much more likely to switch away from Medicare Advantage than the other way around — and this effect was magnified among the dual eligible population, the researchers from Brown and Vanderbilt universities found. "Our findings raise questions about the role of Medicare Advantage plans in serving high-cost patients with complex care needs, who account for a disproportionately high amount of total health care spending," they wrote. The research: http://bit.ly/1FyXAQN
ALMOST 9 IN 10 GAY ADULTS ARE NOW COVERED — That's compared to about 78 percent who had coverage before the ACA. But lesbian, gay and bisexual adults still face greater challenges accessing and affording care, according to another Health Affairs study. Though, researchers said the Supreme Court’s gay marriage decision this year could open access to coverage by employers, Medicaid, Medicare and the VA, and marriage equality could also reduce social stigma, improve discrimination rates and even improve physical and mental health for gay adults, they write. More: http://bit.ly/1MUCV9Q 
INSURING PRE-EXISTING CONDITIONS, WITHOUT THE ACA — Former CBO director Doug Holtz-Eakin is outlining how the market could incentivize better coverage for this group. His latest essay is one of seven produced by the Mercatus Center at GMU focused on this question, and touches on ideas like barring insurers from discriminating in cases where a patient has continuously been covered, no matter under which plan. More here: http://bit.ly/1MUL4em 
WHAT WE'RE READING, by Jennifer Haberkorn
Exiting House Speaker John Boehner and Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi are "quietly exploring a possible deal that would limit the expected increase in Medicare premiums," The New York Times reports. http://nyti.ms/1FTRavN
The mother of the stillborn baby featured in one of the Center for Medical Progress videos said she did not consent to having her son's picture distributed but she is not mad that the photo was included, according to The Washington Post. http://wapo.st/1LfcjRu
Wellmark, the dominant health insurer in Iowa, will start selling Obamacare-compliant policies in one year, the Des Moines Register reports. http://dmreg.co/1Q33Xwe
This year's flu shot is expected to be more effective than the combination released in prior years, according to USA Today. http://usat.ly/1LuCC8r
Hawaii has approved 27.3 percent and 34.4 percent rate hikes for insurance policies next year, the Honolulu Star Advertiser reports. http://bit.ly/1jaAkyS
Someone "matched" on Tinder with drugmaker Martin Shkreli, who has earned the scorn of the nation, and wrote about it. http://bit.ly/1OiOElJ
JOIN US — WOMEN RULE: TAKING RISKS AND TAKING CHARGE Women Rule live event series returns Wednesday morning at 8 am with “Women Rule: Taking Risks and Taking Charge,” a series of conversations with women who have braved the odds in their lives and careers. Vian Dakhil, Iraqi MP and voice of the Yazidi people being attacked by ISIS and her sister, Dr. Deelan Dakhil, the co-director of the Sinjar Foundation will headline the event. Featured speakers also include Sen. Tammy Baldwin (D-Wis.); Sarah LaFleur, Founder and CEO, MM. LaFleur, and former White House NSA and EVP of MacAndrews and Forbes, Frances Fragos Townsend. RSVP:http://politi.co/1KKCkDP 
** A message from the American College of Rheumatology: More than 63 million Americans are living with doctor-diagnosed arthritis, autoimmune diseases such as lupus, or inflammatory rheumatic diseases such as gout and psoriatic arthritis. Many of these individuals are at risk for chronic pain, organ damage, disability and even death as a result of their diagnosis.
Advocates for Arthritis are visiting Capitol Hill today [this week] to increase awareness about rheumatic diseases and elevate policy issues affecting the rheumatology community. Rheumatology professionals and patients from across the country are asking Congress to support policies to ensure access to quality care for America’s rheumatology patients, including limited patient cost sharing for specialty therapies, increased funding for disease research and less restrictive insurer practices. 
The American College of Rheumatology (ACR) is a professional membership organization committed to improving the care of patients with rheumatic disease and advancing the rheumatology subspecialty.
Visit rheumatology.org/Advocacy to learn more. Follow the conversation at #Act4Arthritis. **
Erin Mershon is a health care reporter for POLITICO Pro. Before she joined the team, she covered technology policy for POLITICO and for Communications Daily. She's covered nearly every aspect of Congress, from its Eagle Scout members to its wonkiest procedural maneuverings, for National Journal, Roll Call, The Huffington Post and PolitiFact. She's a graduate of Kenyon College, where she studied political science and ran the college newspaper. 
Mershon is a Cincinnati, Ohio, native and an occasional oil painter. She loves crossword puzzles and colorful pens.
